awd_titl_txt: Research on Effects of Integrating Computational Science and Model Building in Water Systems Teaching and Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
As computational capabilities increasingly revolutionize and become integral to the practice of science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) disciplines, the STEM+Computing (STEM+C) Partnerships program seeks to integrate the use of computational approaches in K-12 STEM teaching and learning.   The Comp Hydro project will address the goals of the STEM+C program, as well as an urgent issue facing society: the availability of clean water as an ecosystem service supporting human uses and ecological integrity.  The vision of Comp Hydro is to foster water and computational science literacy by integrating authentic, place- and data-based learning as high school students build and use physical, mathematical and conceptual models.  The approaches and resources of Comp Hydro will be developed in a broad diversity of settings - types of schools and school systems, student and teacher populations, instructional contexts, and regional challenges and constraints on water quality and availability. Teams in four locations around the country will adapt surface water- and groundwater-themed computer modules to local environmental and school contexts, will pilot test them in high school Earth and environmental science classes, and will partner in education research on student and teacher STEM learning. Approximately 2,400 students will be involved with and benefit from the project. The diverse nature of the participating school districts will both engage a demographically diverse student population in STEM and help the project achieve significant broader impacts, by assuring that the findings and tools developed reflect the needs of a broad diversity of people and places.   Through curricular resource creation and professional development for teachers, Comp Hydro will help to build the capacity of each school district to integrate computational and environmental science.  Instructional materials based on learning progressions will support students in developing water science literacy required for informed citizen decision-making. 

The Comp Hydro project will address one of the most daunting challenges to developing scientific literacy in students: integrating teaching and learning of key ideas and practices of place-based environmental science with computational and quantitative science in authentic, innovative and effective ways. The basic premise of the project is that to achieve model-based reasoning in environmental science, a student needs to concurrently develop more sophisticated computational reasoning. Four curriculum/professional development modules will be developed to integrate Earth system and computational thinking content.  They will focus on these computational concepts and practices: ability to access and manipulate data from multiple sources; ability to use computational tools to develop models, analyze data, produce data visualizations, and identify key trends; application of computational reasoning and model-based understanding to construct quantitative, scientific explanations and predictions regarding hydrologic systems.  The project will: 1) develop and refine instructional units for surface and groundwater, each comprising two 1-week modules, 2) engage teachers as partners and agents of dissemination, 3) study teacher and student learning, 4) explore supports and constraints on teaching, and 5) build a platform for project research and development and dissemination. The project will engage four teams of 6 teachers, who will work over two school years with educators and scientists at four diverse sites (Arizona, Colorado, Maryland, and Montana).  Comp Hydro will utilize a design-based research approach, grounded in learning progressions as a theoretical and methodological frame, for both its research and instructional materials. The project will integrate computational and data sense making practices and understandings into the Water Systems Learning Progression. It will produce a trajectory of learning and associated assessment instruments that can describe how students become more sophisticated with respect to integrated scientific practices, including analyzing, interpreting and representing data; developing and using models; using computational thinking; and constructing scientific explanations and predictions about hydrologic systems. The project also will develop a set of design principles, and an associated computer platform for broader dissemination and for supporting teachers in integrating the use of big and small data sets into meaningful environmental science learning experiences with high school students.

por.por_cntn:
Our project studied water and computational science literacy using physical, mathematical, and conceptual models of hydrologic systems. We hypothesized that the incorporation of computational science concepts and practices into high school level water-related courses would enhance achievement of both. We tested this hypothesis through design and implementation of scientific modeling-based learning experiences that studied high school student reasoning about hydrologic systems using physical, computational, and conceptual scientific models. The project had five objectives.

Objective 1: Develop and test instructional modules that integrate scientific and computational learning about hydrologic systems.

Objective 2: Develop and conduct teacher professional development that supports integration of computational thinking and practice into water systems education.

Objective 3: Investigate how the integration of data modeling and computational thinking into Earth and environmental science courses supports student and teacher development of model-based understanding of hydrologic systems and use of computational practices to model and interpret data.

Objective 4: Investigate teachers? experiences and perceptions of integrating computational thinking into instruction to learn how to support teachers in engaging in these instructional practices.

Objective 5: Build a digital support platform to facilitate the development and use of the modules (objectives 1 and 2) and the proposed research (objectives 3 and 4).

For objectives 1 and 2 we provided high school teachers in Arizona, Colorado, Maryland and Montana with training on the development and use of physical and computer-based models of hydrologic systems. The teachers integrated a suite of agent-based models using NetLogo and physical models of hydrological systems into instructional modules for use in their classrooms. The instructional modules shared common hydrologic content and principles but were adapted to regional contexts and state STEM standards in each state. The units were used to teach content and concepts, and were used as research instruments to develop a learning progression for hydrologic principles and the importance of computational thinking and applications skills in student learning.

For Objectives 3 and 4 we examined how student engagement in computational thinking (science and engineering practice) intertwines (sensu the Framework for K-12 Science Education) with their learning about the flow of water through environmental systems (disciplinary core ideas) and their understanding of systems and system models (crosscutting concept). We first developed an idealized upper anchor to the learning progression that was aligned with state standards. The upper anchor spelled out a level of content proficiency of hydrologic and computational principles and their applications and of the conceptual ability to use these principles and skills across multiple scenarios operating across different scales. We then developed queries within the instructional units that would prompt student responses about the principles and on their abilities to apply model-based hierarchical reasoning. 

For Objective 5 we developed a cloud-based platform - EcoApps - to make computational modeling activities accessible for schools with limited access to hardware, software and IT support. EcoApps is a server-based system that allows teachers and students to access NetLogo models by logging in via the web to a server that houses the models and associated files. EcoApps also captures student responses to queries about the instructional units and their content.

Our findings revealed how the three dimensions of the Framework for K-12 Science Education - science and engineering practices, disciplinary core ideas, and crosscutting concepts - intertwine during learning, and how computational thinking practices facilitate the learning process. First, our learning progression for hydrologic content and concepts possessed three levels of performance on a four level-based learning progression. Students operating at Level 1-2 interacted with models to achieve a specified goal. Students at Level 3 used the computational models to solve real-world problems. Students at Level 4 used computational thinking processes and principles related to systems modeling and hydrology to explain how the models worked to predict water flow.  Second, computational thinking and the use of system models facilitated learning about hydrologic system. As students progressed across levels, their understanding of the systems and system models crosscutting concept aligned with their progress in computational thinking practices and their use of hydrology disciplinary core ideas. Student understanding of water in environmental systems emerged from the intertwining of the three dimensions of the Framework for K-12 Science Education - science and engineering practices, disciplinary core ideas, and crosscutting concepts. Third, not all computational thinking-related practices (e.g., abstraction, quantification, parameterization) need rely on computers, as physical models and paper representations could be used to overcome the challenges related to student access to computers and computer software in the classroom.

We disseminated our results through peer-reviewed publications in journals and book chapters, conference presentations at regional, national and international meetings, as a video showcased by NSF, an instructional video on YouTube, and at professional development workshops supported by the project and at the STEM-C PI meeting hosted by NSF.  The lesson plans are available on the host institution websites.
